Builds the season’s A-plot and Raffi’s B-plot toward a unified conspiracy storyline.

Title: Seventeen Seconds
Antagonists: Vadic and the Shrike
Rogue Founders infiltrating Starfleet
Internal sabotage threatening the Titan

StorySections.Text: A flashback to the post–Dominion War era shows Riker sharing with Picard the terror of riding a turbolift for seventeen seconds while his newborn son’s life hung in the balance. In the present, the Titan reels under the Shrike’s attack inside the nebula, with shields failing and engines crippled. On M’talas Prime, Worf and Raffi begin piecing together the Daystrom heist and its connection to the portal weapon used on the Federation recruitment center.

As the Shrike batters the Titan, Shaw is gravely injured and forced to relinquish command to Riker. Picard takes the opportunity to confront Beverly about years of silence and the mysterious young man now on his ship. Beverly finally admits that Jack is Picard’s son and explains her decision to raise him away from the shadow of Picard’s dangerous, high-profile life in Starfleet.

Reeling from the revelation, Picard tries to reach Jack while Riker shifts tactics to a more defensive posture, hoping to ride out the nebula and buy time. Meanwhile, Worf and Raffi interrogate a captured criminal contact, learn of rogue Changelings operating outside the Great Link, and realize the Daystrom theft was just one step in a broader campaign against the Federation. On the Titan, subtle acts of sabotage begin to point toward a shape-shifter infiltrator on board.

Riker reluctantly allows Picard to take tactical control for an aggressive counterattack against the Shrike, hoping to break free of the nebula’s grasp. The maneuver backfires when Vadic uses the portal weapon to turn the Titan’s own torpedoes against it, sending the ship deeper into the anomaly and closer to destruction. Down in sickbay, Jack is exposed to poison gas vented by the Changeling saboteur, forcing Picard into his own ‘seventeen seconds’ turbolift ride as he races to his son’s side.

Jack survives thanks to Beverly’s quick action, but the Titan is crippled and drifting in the nebula with power failing and escape routes cut off. Riker, furious that Picard’s risky strategy nearly killed them all, orders him off the bridge. Father and son remain at the center of a storm that now threatens not just a ship, but the security of the entire Federation.

EthicalIssues: A parent’s right to decide whether a child should grow up near constant danger and notoriety.
When a commander should override conservative tactics in favor of bold, high-risk maneuvers.
Using painful personal experiences as cautionary tales versus allowing them to paralyze decision-making.
ContinuityNotes: Directly references the Dominion War and the trauma it left on officers like Worf and other veterans.
Reveals the existence of a rogue Changeling faction, expanding on Deep Space Nine’s aftermath.
Picard’s relationship to family and legacy echoes earlier storylines involving his nephew and his lack of heirs.
ThematicNotes: The weight of parenthood and how fear for a child reframes every choice.
How unresolved grief and guilt can fuel conflict between longtime friends.
The danger of repeating old command patterns when circumstances have fundamentally changed.
BehindTheScenes: Directed by Jonathan Frakes, allowing Riker’s emotional arc to be shaped by the actor himself.
Blends submarine-style starship combat with intimate family drama at the heart of the episode.
Continues the season’s cinematic visual approach to space battles inside the nebula.

Title: No Win Scenario
GuestCharacters: Young officers in Ten Forward LA
Antagonists: Vadic and the Shrike
The collapsing nebula threatening to tear the Titan apart
The lingering trauma of past battles

StorySections.Text: In a flashback at Ten Forward in Los Angeles years earlier, Picard regales a group of young Starfleet cadets with embellished tales of past glories, insisting that Starfleet has always been the only family he needed. In the present, that confidence is gone as the Titan, crippled inside the nebula, drifts toward certain destruction with life support fading and no apparent escape.

Riker, convinced that aggressive tactics nearly killed them, has committed the ship to a defensive posture that now offers only a slow death. Shaw, stuck in sickbay, needles Picard about Wolf 359 and unloads years of trauma over having once served on a ship that survived the Borg attack. Jack watches from the sidelines, hearing for the first time how Picard’s history looks from the victims’ perspective.

Picard and Jack talk in the holodeck recreation of Ten Forward, where Jack questions why Picard never sought a more personal life and what ‘family’ really means to him. Beverly and the science team study the nebula’s strange energy pulses and realize it may be a living anomaly going through cyclical contractions that could, in theory, be harnessed like a slingshot. The crew must decide whether to gamble everything on a desperate, untested plan.

Riker and Picard reconcile enough to work the problem together, combining their instincts and experience. They line the Titan’s hull with explosive charges and adjust the ship’s trajectory to ride the nebula’s next contraction, hoping the blast and wave will hurl them clear. Vadic, expecting an easy kill outside, watches in disbelief as the Titan bursts free of the anomaly and deals serious damage to the Shrike before warping away.

Safe for the moment, the Titan crew celebrates a hard-won victory while Picard quietly recognizes that his definition of family has changed. Shaw grudgingly acknowledges Picard’s skill, even if the scars of Wolf 359 remain. Jack is left contemplating what it means to be the son of a man whose greatest triumphs are inseparable from some of Starfleet’s darkest days.

EthicalIssues: Reviving morale and purpose when a crew believes they are doomed.
How much truth a legendary officer owes to younger generations who idolize him.
Risking the last hope of survival on a wild, unproven scientific theory.
ContinuityNotes: Revisits Wolf 359 from the perspective of a survivor who blames Locutus of Borg, deepening Picard’s long-standing guilt.
Echoes the Starfleet ‘no-win scenario’ training exercises introduced in Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan.
Further cements Ten Forward LA as a recurring personal touchstone in Picard’s later life.
ThematicNotes: The idea that the only true no-win scenario is the refusal to change or to try.
How legends can obscure the painful cost behind great victories.
Family as something you choose and build, not just the uniform you wear.
BehindTheScenes: Structured around an emotional parallel between Picard’s barroom storytelling and present-day crisis leadership.
Uses the nebula’s pseudo-organic nature to provide classic Star Trek ‘mystery of space’ science fiction.
Allows Todd Stashwick’s Shaw to deliver a cathartic monologue about Wolf 359 that resonated with many viewers.

Title: Imposters
GuestCharacters: Starfleet security officers under Changeling influence
Antagonists: Rogue Changeling infiltrators inside Starfleet Command
Saboteurs pursuing the Daystrom heist
Layers of mistrust between former allies

StorySections.Text: With the Titan limping to a remote rendezvous, Picard and Riker brace to face the consequences of disobeying orders and nearly losing a starship. Starfleet dispatches a security vessel to take them into custody for court-martial, just as Worf and Raffi’s investigation on M’talas Prime reveals that the Daystrom break-in involved more than just a stolen portal weapon.

The security team’s commander is revealed to be Ro Laren, the former Bajoran ensign whose defection to the Maquis decades earlier shattered Picard’s trust. Ro treats Picard and Riker as potential traitors, subjecting them to intense questioning while subtly testing for signs that they might be Changelings. The wounds of their past clash with the present-day crisis as Picard accuses her of betraying everything Starfleet stands for.

Through a tense, layered conversation, Ro and Picard gradually recognize that their raw emotions, cultural pain, and deep knowledge of each other cannot be faked by shape-shifters. Ro reveals that she returned to Starfleet, rose in Intelligence, and has uncovered undeniable evidence that rogue Founders have infiltrated Starfleet at the highest levels. She believes the Titan and its crew are now targets in a much larger plot.

Ro secretly arms Picard and transfers her remaining, trusted security officers to the Titan, confessing that she has little time left to act. She returns to her own ship, only to discover her crew has already been replaced by Changelings. Sabotaged and doomed, Ro pilots her shuttle into the security ship’s nacelle, sacrificing herself to cripple the compromised vessel while transmitting crucial data to Picard.

Grieving but galvanized, Picard realizes that his unresolved anger toward Ro nearly cost him the warning she died to deliver. He convinces Shaw to take the Titan fully rogue to investigate the conspiracy and protect what remains of their uninfected allies. Meanwhile, Worf and Raffi prepare to infiltrate Daystrom Station itself to learn exactly what the Changelings stole.

EthicalIssues: How much trust can be rebuilt when a former protégé’s past choices shattered it.
The risks of going underground against a conspiracy embedded within legitimate authority.
The morality of sacrificing oneself to cripple a compromised Starfleet vessel.
ContinuityNotes: Brings back Ro Laren and directly addresses the unresolved fallout from her final TNG appearance.
Confirms that the Maquis-era decisions continued to define Ro’s relationship with Starfleet for decades.
Expands the idea of Dominion infiltration tactics into the post–DS9 era with more subtle, long-term strategies.
ThematicNotes: The difficulty of distinguishing imposters from imperfect people trying to make amends.
How old betrayals can blind even wise leaders to genuine change.
Trust as both a vulnerability and a weapon in times of paranoia.
BehindTheScenes: Michelle Forbes returns as Ro Laren after decades away from the role.
The episode functions as a spiritual sequel to TNG’s ‘Preemptive Strike,’ providing emotional closure.
Uses Ro’s sacrifice to pivot the season fully into political thriller territory.

Title: The Bounty
Antagonists: Rogue Changelings embedded in Starfleet and Daystrom Station
The legacy of Soong-type android experimentation
Vadic’s pursuit and surveillance of the Titan

StorySections.Text: The Titan hides near the Fleet Museum while Starfleet broadcasts sanitized updates about the terrorist threat, masking the scale of Changeling infiltration. Worf and Raffi rendezvous with the Titan after a high-risk mission to Daystrom Station, where they encountered a mysterious new android that holds the key to the heist.

An away team returns to Daystrom using stolen access codes, where they encounter the Daystrom Android M-5-10, an advanced synthetic housing memories from Data, Lore, B-4, and Altan Soong. The android’s fragmented personalities guard a trove of classified projects. By decoding fragmented clues, they learn that the Changelings did not steal the portal weapon itself—it was a decoy to conceal the theft of Picard’s human remains.

Meanwhile, Picard, Jack, and Seven visit the Fleet Museum, where retired Commodore Geordi La Forge oversees an array of legendary starships. Jack and Seven marvel at relics like the Defiant and Voyager, while Picard tries to pull Geordi into the fight. Geordi resists, torn between his duty to the museum, his daughters’ safety, and loyalty to his old captain.

Realizing the Changeling plot must involve Picard’s unique Borg-altered biology, the crew rushes to get the Daystrom Android off-station before the infiltrators can reclaim it. Geordi ultimately agrees to help, using his intimate knowledge of starship systems to mask the Titan’s movements and integrate the android into their network. The core personalities inside the synthetic body flicker between Data’s warmth and Lore’s malice, hinting at internal conflict still to come.

Safely back aboard the Titan with Geordi, his daughters, and the Daystrom Android, the crew takes stock of their stolen advantage. Jack continues to experience strange visions and an unsettling pull he cannot explain. The bounty Vadic has placed on him now appears to be tied less to his crimes and more to whatever the Changelings intend to do with the remains of Jean-Luc Picard.

EthicalIssues: Using the remains of a deceased person, even a legendary admiral, for classified research without clear consent.
Whether Geordi is justified in prioritizing his daughters’ safety over assisting his former captain.
The morality of combining multiple sentient personalities into a single synthetic body.
ContinuityNotes: Reveals that Picard’s body, altered by assimilation, has remained of intense scientific interest after his death and synthetic rebirth.
Shows multiple legacy starships at the Fleet Museum, including vessels from Deep Space Nine and Voyager eras.
Advances Data’s long-running storyline by resurrecting aspects of him in a new, merged android form.
ThematicNotes: The weight of legacy technology and how old weapons and ships keep shaping new crises.
Parents’ conflicting duties to family and to the ideals they once served.
Identity as a patchwork of memories, code, and choices rather than a single static self.
BehindTheScenes: Brings back LeVar Burton as Geordi La Forge along with on-screen daughters played by Mica Burton and Ashlei Sharpe Chestnut.
Provides a tour of fan-favorite starships, functioning as a visual celebration of Star Trek history.
Uses the Daystrom Android to bridge Data’s previous ‘death’ with a new status quo for Brent Spiner’s character.

Title: Dominion
GuestCharacters: Bridge officers held hostage by Vadic
Starfleet prisoners secretly replaced by Changelings
Scientists from the clandestine Section 31 program (mentioned in backstory)
Antagonists: Vadic and her rogue Changeling faction
Legacy bioweapons and unethical experiments from the Dominion War era
Paranoia threatening to fracture the Titan’s crew

StorySections.Text: The Titan hides among derelict ships in a cemetery from the Dominion War, using the debris as cover while the crew debates its next move. Picard and Beverly consider that their enemy understands Starfleet tactics as well as they do, while Vadic stalks them in the dark, increasingly frustrated that Jack continues to elude capture.

Picard and his senior staff devise a risky plan to lure Vadic aboard by faking catastrophic damage and broadcasting a distress signal. Seven is tasked with drawing out suspected Changeling infiltrators among their crew, while Geordi and Data work to counter enemy control over the Titan’s systems. Jack continues to display unsettling telepathic-like abilities that hint at a deeper connection to the threat.

Vadic and her forces board the Titan, walking into a trap of force fields and sealed bulkheads. Isolated and interrogated, Vadic reveals she was one of many Changelings grotesquely experimented upon by Section 31 during the Dominion War, a survivor of torture who now seeks vengeance on the Federation. Her bitter monologue forces Picard and Beverly to confront the horrors committed in the name of peace.

The plan collapses when Changeling saboteurs seize control of the ship’s systems, freeing Vadic and turning the Titan’s security measures against its own crew. Vadic captures key officers on the bridge, taunts Picard over the internal comms, and demands Jack’s surrender. Beverly and Picard privately debate whether they can use the original morphogenic virus—or some derivative—against Vadic’s faction, and what that would make them.

Ultimately rejecting the immediate use of a genocidal bioweapon, Picard and Beverly refuse to become the monsters Vadic believes them to be. However, their moral stand leaves the Titan firmly in Vadic’s grip as she seizes the bridge and turns the ship toward her unknown masters. The Dominion War’s scars, long buried, have now come roaring back into the open.

EthicalIssues: The long-term consequences of using biological weapons, even in wartime, on sentient opponents.
Whether the Federation bears ongoing responsibility to those it tortured in secret programs.
If reusing a genocidal virus against a splinter group can ever be ethically justified.
ContinuityNotes: Revisits the Dominion War and Section 31’s use of the morphogenic virus against Changelings.
Establishes Vadic as a direct survivor of Federation war crimes, complicating the moral landscape.
Connects the Titan’s hiding place to famous battlefields from Deep Space Nine’s later seasons.
ThematicNotes: The idea that history’s unacknowledged sins will eventually demand a reckoning.
How vengeance can reshape victims into the very threat their oppressors always feared.
Choosing not to repeat past atrocities, even when doing so seems tactically advantageous.
BehindTheScenes: Expands Amanda Plummer’s performance as Vadic with a tragic, rage-fueled backstory.
Leans into horror-thriller visuals as Vadic hunts through the Titan’s corridors.
Visually links the Dominion War graveyard to iconic starship wreckage familiar to longtime fans.

Title: Surrender
GuestCharacters: Captured Starfleet officers on the Shrike
Antagonists: Vadic in full control of the Titan
Lore’s disruptive personality inside the android body
The Borg-linked impulses pushing Jack toward reckless action

StorySections.Text: Vadic has seized the Titan’s bridge, holding its officers at gunpoint and broadcasting a chilling ultimatum throughout the ship. She demands Jack’s surrender and threatens to execute crew members one by one until he complies. In the brig of the Shrike, Riker and Troi face their own captivity, unsure if anyone even knows where they are.

Picard and Beverly struggle with Jack’s insistence that he turn himself over to stop the bloodshed. Jack reveals that he can hear and subtly influence other people through some kind of psychic link, abilities that terrify him as much as they intrigue him. Geordi and his daughters work in the engine room to awaken the Daystrom Android’s dormant potential, hoping Data’s persona can help them take back the ship.

Inside the synthetic mind, Data and Lore battle for control, with Lore attempting to overwrite Data’s personality by absorbing his memories. Rather than fight in kind, Data offers up his most precious moments—Tasha’s hologram, Spot, friendships on the Enterprise—overwhelming Lore with the very humanity he always coveted. Outside, Vadic’s patience runs thin as she torments the hostages and taunts Seven about her divided loyalties.

Data’s gambit succeeds as Lore, unable to distinguish himself from the flood of memories, effectively dissolves into Data’s expanded sense of self. Regaining full control of the body, Data reasserts his identity and seizes the Titan’s systems, coordinating with Seven to trigger force fields and turn the tables on Vadic. Simultaneously, Worf and Raffi storm the Shrike, rescuing Riker and Troi in a flurry of efficient violence and wry banter.

Vadic is blown out into space and shatters against her own ship, the Shrike soon destroyed by the Titan’s weapons. For the first time in days, the crew has breathing room, and a fully realized Data stands among his friends once more. Yet Jack, haunted by his abilities and the sense of a greater design behind them, chooses not to surrender—but to go on the offensive and seek the source of the voice calling to him.

EthicalIssues: Whether Jack has the right to sacrifice himself to protect the crew over his parents’ objections.
The question of identity and consent when one personality effectively absorbs another within a single body.
What methods are justified when retaking a hijacked starship full of hostages.
ContinuityNotes: Resolves the long-standing Data–Lore rivalry, merging them into a singular, more complex Data.
Reunites the core Next Generation cast—Picard, Riker, Troi, Worf, Data, Geordi—on the same side of a crisis.
Further develops Jack’s unexplained abilities, foreshadowing their connection to the Borg.
ThematicNotes: Surrender as a choice between giving up and letting go of the pain that defines you.
The power of cherished memories as the foundation of personhood.
Family—by blood and by choice—as the force that rescues people from isolation and despair.
BehindTheScenes: Gives Brent Spiner space to play both Data and Lore in an internal psychological duel.
Features Worf’s blend of fierce combat and dry humor in the Shrike rescue sequence.
Marks the effective end of Vadic’s storyline, clearing the way for the season’s final act.

Title: Vox
GuestCharacters: Young Starfleet officers assimilated via transporter code
Antagonists: The Borg collective lurking behind Jack’s visions
Changeling agents who rewrote Starfleet transporter code
The automated Starfleet armada slaved together on Frontier Day

StorySections.Text: With Vadic defeated, the Titan crew gathers to finally examine the question at the heart of the conspiracy: what do the Changelings want with Jack Crusher and Picard’s altered biology? Troi agrees to help Jack confront the recurring red door in his mind, hoping that whatever lies beyond will reveal the truth before Frontier Day’s massive fleet ceremony begins.

In a guided mental journey, Troi leads Jack down the corridor of his nightmares and through the red door, where they find not simple trauma but the unmistakable presence of a Borg Cube. Jack is revealed as the ‘voice’—a receiver and transmitter of a new kind of Borg signal, the product of changes the Changelings made using Picard’s stolen Borg-affected tissue. Horrified, Jack flees the ship in a shuttle, determined to confront the Borg alone before he can be used as a weapon.

As Frontier Day begins in Earth orbit, Admiral Shelby presides over a demonstration of Starfleet’s new fleet synchronization technology, linking starships into a single, responsive armada. On the Titan, Picard and his crew realize too late that the transporter system—already used on most young officers—has implanted Borg genetic code across Starfleet. A signal from the hidden Borg activates the implants, assimilating officers under a certain age and turning the fleet against its own people.

Chaos erupts as assimilated young officers seize control of ships and systems, slaughtering or imprisoning their unaltered crewmates. Shaw, Seven, and a handful of older officers fight a desperate rear-guard action to keep the Titan free long enough for the senior TNG-era crew to escape. Picard, Riker, Troi, Data, Geordi, and Worf flee to the Fleet Museum, following Geordi’s cryptic promise that he has been working on something special in secret.

In the museum’s hidden bay, Geordi reveals a fully restored USS Enterprise-D, painstakingly rebuilt from salvaged parts and upgraded for the 25th century. The old crew takes their positions at the familiar bridge, the moment framed as both homecoming and last stand. With Starfleet in Borg-controlled chaos and Jack in the hands of the enemy, the Enterprise-D launches once more to save Earth—and perhaps the Federation itself.

EthicalIssues: Embedding genetic ‘safeguards’ or modifications into transporter routines without fully informed consent.
The danger of centralizing control of a military fleet under a single coordinating system.
Jack’s attempt to face the Borg alone as an act of self-sacrifice that may instead empower the enemy.

Title: The Last Generation
GuestCharacters: Fleet civilians and officers under Borg control
Antagonists: The Borg Queen and the hidden Cube in Jupiter orbit
The assimilated Starfleet armada attacking Earth
The temptation to accept that some futures cannot be saved

StorySections.Text: Earth and its surrounding defenses burn under the attack of a Borg-controlled Starfleet, as ships fire on Spacedock and civilian targets in a chilling echo of Wolf 359. A distress message from Federation President Anton Chekov warns any survivors to stay away from the Sol System. Aboard the Enterprise-D, Picard and his crew realize that the source of the control signal lies within a massive Borg Cube hidden inside Jupiter’s storms.

With no way to stop the fleet from outside, the crew splits their efforts. Seven and Raffi lead resistance efforts aboard the Titan, trying to protect unassimilated crew and civilians while searching for any way to disrupt the Borg link. On the Enterprise-D, Data pilots the ship through lethal debris and planetary defenses toward the Cube, while Picard, Riker, and Worf prepare for a dangerous landing and infiltration mission.

Inside the Cube, the away team follows Jack’s psychic imprint through decaying corridors filled with half-dead drones and organic machinery. They discover the Borg Queen, grotesquely sustained by harvested drones and connected to Jack at the center of a new, more insidious collective. The Queen reveals her alliance with the rogue Changelings and her plan to replace Starfleet’s ‘old generation’ with a younger, fully Borg-altered one.

As the Titan makes a desperate run on Spacedock’s control systems, Seven and Raffi rally a small band of unassimilated officers to hold off the Borg-controlled fleet. In the Cube, Picard links his mind to Jack’s, entering the collective to reach his son from within. Instead of trying to pull Jack away by force, Picard offers unconditional love and the promise of a life chosen freely, not dictated by any legacy—Borg or Picard.

Jack rejects the Queen’s control, severing the signal and triggering the Cube’s destruction as the Enterprise-D escapes at the last possible moment. Across the system, assimilated officers regain themselves and the fleet stands down. In the aftermath, the Titan-A is rechristened the Enterprise-G under Captain Seven of Nine, with Raffi as her first officer and Jack serving in a special advisory role. In a final coda, Picard joins his old friends for one last poker game, their story closing on laughter, shared memory, and the sense that while this may be the last generation of this crew, their legacy will continue to echo through the stars.
